data.title: The Tragedy of Julia the Elder

data.text:
I just recently finished watching the second season of MGM+’s historical drama Domina and, while the series is focused on Livia, the wife of Augustus (and Rome’s first de facto empress), I was just as fascinated by one of the secondary characters: the woman known to historians as Julia the Elder. Despite her status as the only child of Augustus, the series makes clear, repeatedly, that her life was not a particularly happy one, as she was repeatedly used by her father to further his own plots and plans, regardless of what her own wishes and desires might have been. Determined to mold Rome in his own image, Augustus used his daughter like a piece in a great chessgame, moving her around as he saw fit.

Indeed, from the beginning Julia’s life was marred by tragedy and unrest. She was taken from mother Scribonia by her father and placed into the custody of his third wife, Livia Drusilla, who did all she could to mold her stepdaughter into the proper kind of matron.
